title: Loops: For and While
description: Iterate cleanly through sequences and ranges.

content.text: Loops allow your program to repeat actions multiple times. Python has two main types of loops: for loops and while loops. Using loops helps you avoid writing repetitive code.
A for loop iterates over a sequence, such as a list, string, or range. For example, for i in range(3): print(i) will print 0, 1, 2. The loop runs once for each element in the sequence.

content.prompt: Use a for loop to print all items in the list fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry'].

content.text: A while loop repeats as long as a condition is true. For example, x = 0; while x < 3: print(x); x += 1 prints 0, 1, 2. Be careful: if the condition never becomes false, the loop runs forever.

content.prompt: Use a while loop to print numbers from 1 to 5.

content.text: You can use break to exit a loop early and continue to skip to the next iteration. This is useful when you need to stop based on a condition or skip certain elements without stopping the entire loop.

content.prompt: Use a for loop to print numbers from 1 to 5, but skip 3 using continue.

content.text: Loops can be nested inside each other. For example, you can have a for loop inside another for loop to iterate over a grid or matrix. Each loop has its own variable and scope.

content.prompt: Use nested loops to print a 2x2 grid of coordinates (x, y) where x and y are 0 or 1.

content.text: Reflection: You learned how to use for and while loops, control loop execution with break and continue, and nest loops for complex iterations. Loops are a fundamental tool for performing repetitive tasks efficiently in Python.
